risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Registered Social Worker & Masters of Social Work, Veterinary Social Work, Ontario Veterinary College and Health Sciences Centre, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON, Canada

sect2.title: 14.1 Introduction
sect2.para: Veterinary technicians involved in end‐of‐life (EOL) care work closely with grieving clients and families, so it is important that technicians have an understanding of grief. In doing so, technicians will enhance their professional skills and personal resilience, providing a compassionate EOL experience for clients, patients, and the veterinary team.

Grief is a process that happens as a response to meaningful loss. It is an inevitable human experience, yet despite its commonality, grief is easily misunderstood. In a North American context, there tends to be discomfort with grief, as it is often accompanied by deep pain, loss, and longing. It is an experience that people seek to avoid or quickly resolvech0027-c14-bib-0001. Unfortunately, this view and approach to death encourages minimizing grief, treating it as a problem that needs to be fixed rather than a normal, emotional process.

This chapter will take a closer look at what it means to grieve the loss of a companion animal by examining the fundamentals of grief, the unique context of loss in the human–animal bond (HAB), different grief responses, and factors that influence these responses. Technicians will gain a better understanding of the impact of pet loss not only for the clients they work with but also for themselves and their teams.

sect2.title: 14.2 The Fundamentals of Grief
sect2.para: It is important that technicians know the basics of grief. Recognizing how grief manifests will help technicians understand why client responses to pet loss can vary, and it will also help them gain perspective that grief is a normal, healthy part of life.

para.emphasis: Take a few moments to write down your understanding of grief.
Consider what experiences or influences have shaped this perspective for you.

entry.para: Refers to the inward experience that happens leading to and after a loss of any kind.
Refers to the outward expression of loss. Even though an individual grieves that does not necessarily mean they express this grief openly ormourn.
Bereavement refers to the period after a loss has occurred. The bereaved (person who has experienced the loss) is grieving or mourning during this time, processing the loss and adjusting to it.

sidebar.title: Case Study 14.1 Diane, Christian, and Speckle
sidebar.para: Two partners, Diane and Christian, are at their regular veterinary practice for a euthanasia appointment. They are saying goodbye to Speckle, their cat of eight years, whom they adopted shortly after they began dating. During and after the euthanasia procedure, Diane is openly distressed, she is crying and verbally expressing her sadness. She shares memories of how special Speckle was with the technician and veterinarian in the room. Meanwhile, her partner Christian remains reserved. He shares that he is sad and sheds some silent tears for a moment, but then remains quiet and lets Diane do the talking. The technician who attended the euthanasia focuses on comforting and reassuring Diane, offers sympathy for both of their losses, and provides resources for the couple to take home.

sect2.para: The first step to understanding grief is to be familiar with its terminology. There are certain words that come up often in this subject, and they are sometimes used interchangeably. These words hold different meanings that can help technicians put a name to and describe what is happening when someone suffers a loss.Table 14.1 below identifies and clarifies common terms and their definitions which technicians can practice applying with Case Study 14.1.

Technicians should be mindful of how grief, mourning, and bereavement are influenced by factors such as an individual’s personality, age, spirituality, cultural norms, and interpersonal relationships. Technicians are not expected to be grief experts, but they can use this knowledge to better support clients and navigate their personal grief experiences.

Now that the terminology has been explained, what does the grief process look like for someone experiencing a significant loss like a companion animal? A well‐recognized theory applied to answering this question is called Stage Theory. Stage theory is widely recognized in North America and has shaped societal perceptions around what it means and looks like to grieve. This theory is responsible for explaining the process of grief through the popular five stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptancech0027-c14-bib-0002. The five stages explain that grief is an experience that happens in a typical sequence of emotions and behaviors, or stages. Stage theory was developed by Dr. Elisabeth Kubler‐Ross in her publication On Death and Dying ch0027-c14-bib-0002. Dr. Kubler‐Ross’s research documented observations of human patients who were actively dying and in palliative care. Even though the original intention of her work focused on the experience of those who were dying, Stage Theory became applied to the experience of those who were grieving.

The assumption that grief follows a predictable, linear, and timely path is misleading. Grief is highly individualized. Although the emotions and reactions described in the five stages may be part of someone’s experience, they do not necessarily occur in a specific order, or at all. Each person navigates grief uniquely (see Figure 14.1).

sect2.para: Since the debut of Stage Theory, researchers have sought to redefine what it means to grieve and clarify misconceptions commonly held about grieving.Table 14.2 outlines common myths about grief alongside the corresponding facts.

sect2.title: 14.3 The Human–Animal Bond: A Unique Loss
sect2.para: Anyone who has loved and cared for a pet can recognize the special bond between humans and animals (seeFigure 14.2). The HAB has been around for an exceptionally long time and has continued to evolve throughout history. Scientific literature formally recognizes the HAB, and researchers investigate to better understand it. For example, a survey conducted by the Human Animal Bond Research Institute found that 95% of pet parents worldwide consider their companion animals to be part of their family’s structure and dynamic ch0027-c14-bib-0003. The HAB is also one of the only relationships described as unconditional and unspoken. Companion animals may not speak the same language as their caretakers, yet they still find a way to connect and communicate with them on a deep and meaningful level.

The benefits and unique elements of the HAB are far‐reaching and beyond the scope of this chapter. What technicians should be aware of is the impact and importance of the HAB in fulfilling social roles for human beings. For example, the way that people spend time with their companion
animals is often quite different from how they spend time with other people. Companion animals can foster connections among people who share interests in animal‐related activities or causes, reducing isolation and offering social connections within the larger community. The unconditional love and caregiving responsibilities of companion animals can benefit human beings both physically and emotionally. Pets can be a reason to get up and stay active during the day or even act as a calming presence during periods of anxiety and stress. Pets provide a sense of purpose for those who care for them, all while being sources of entertainment, giving nonjudgmental support, and demonstrating affection to those they love and trust.

Table 14.2
Myths and facts about grief.

entry.para: MYTH: After six months the bereaved will reach an endpoint and get over their loss.
FACT: There is no allotted endpoint in grief, the bereaved instead find a way to weave the loss into their life.
MYTH: People who do not show their grief right away are not really that sad.
FACT: Grief presents differently in each person. If someone is not openly mourning right away it doesn’t mean they aren’t sad.
MYTH: It is unhealthy for bereaved persons to experience intense “bursts” of distress or sadness.
FACT: Grief “bursts” are healthy and normal. They might be triggered by memories, visual reminders, smells, certain times of day …etc. Intense waves of extreme emotion are common.
MYTH: There are five stages of grief that the bereaved must experience to obtain closure.
FACT: Grief is not linear. Grief does not transpire in neat, organized stages.
MYTH: Time will heal the pain of the loss, so grief has an endpoint.
FACT: The passage of time can help, but time alone does not heal grief. Professional support may be necessary. Grief is something people learn to live with, it does not end, it integrates.
MYTH: Grieving is reserved for the death of living beings.
FACT: Grief is not just reserved for the death of living beings as grief can occur with losses such as the loss of a job or the ending of a relationship.
MYTH: There is a right way to grieve and a wrong way.
FACT: Grief is a healthy, normal, and human experience that has a variety of manifestations and is unique to each person. There is no one way to do it.
MYTH: The most difficult of all losses is human loss.
FACT: There is no hierarchy or comparison for grief, every grief experience can be different.
MYTH: All emotions felt in grief are painful, such as sadness or anger.
FACT: There can be a range of emotions experienced in grief, not just painful ones. People can experience joy, happiness, relief, love, etc.

sect2.para: Considering all the elements that make this bond special and significant, an intense bond often equals intense grief when a beloved pet dies. There is no hierarchy when it comes to grief, and there are no rules that dictate that one loss is more valued than another. In fact, a grief experience often mirrors the relationship that is lost in intensity and heartbreak.

sect3.title: 14.3.1 Guilt and Regret
sect3.para: Guilt and regret often come up in the context of pet loss, but not necessarily because an individual has something to genuinely feel guilty about or regret. One of the unique aspects of the HAB is how deeply this relationship integrates into people’s lives. Many take on a perceived parental or guardian role for their companions. Pet caregivers proudly take on the responsibility of loving and providing for their pets when they are healthy, sick, or at the EOL.

EOL decision‐making for animals is often cited as guilt‐inducing for pet parents [ch0027-c14-bib-0004, ch0027-c14-bib-0005]. Euthanasia is a common and well‐accepted practice in North American veterinary care. Often, this is a person’s first experience with EOL decision‐making, which can lead to intense feelings of guilt and regret. Even when a person logically recognizes that euthanasia is an appropriate and compassionate choice for their pet, grief may cause them to second‐guess their decisions. Caregivers might feel they had no right to make such a decision for their animal or worry they made it too hastily or too late, blaming themselves for the outcome.

Euthanasia is not the only source of these feelings. Generally, people hold themselves to high standards of care when looking after their pets. After a pet dies, it is common for them to second‐guess their decisions about nutrition, basic care, and treatment, feeling guilty for not noticing signs of a condition or disease earlier. People might even identify that they feel guilty for the sense of relief they experience after the loss, especially if the pet has intense caregiving needs. Sometimes caregivers worry that this relief implies they are glad the pet is gone.

Feelings of guilt and regret are experienced as reality when caregivers grieve. They may feel they failed their pet or were not as loving and caring as they could have been. In truth, those who love their pets deeply never intend for their animals to suffer. Over time, most caregivers gain perspective and recognize that they made the best decisions they could during those times. However, in some cases, guilt and regret can become consuming.

Technicians will hear expressions of guilt and regret from caregivers and can remind them that their decisions were made with love and care, often with the support of the veterinary team. They can help caregivers focus on all the good things they did for their animals, both when they were healthy and when they were ill, to help balance their perspective. There may be times when a technician feels that a client did not provide the best care for their pet and might hesitate to validate the client’s decisions. In such cases, it's helpful to focus on the client’s intent rather than their choices. Most clients make decisions out of love and concern for their pets, and technicians should view these moments as learning opportunities (Case Study 14.2).

sidebar.title: Case Study 14.2 Kasey and Pepper
sidebar.para: Kasey has been visiting a veterinary cardiologist to support their dog, Pepper, who is experiencing congestive heart failure (CHF). One day Kasey notices that Pepper is panting heavily and appearing uncomfortable, so they arrange an urgent appointment with the cardiology team.

During the visit, the veterinary team learns that Kasey has made significant adjustments to Pepper’s heart medication on their own without consultation. Kasey explains that they felt guilty about giving Pepper so much medication, and since Pepper appeared to be improving, lowering the dose couldn’t hurt. The cardiologist firmly explains the risks of altering the medication without guidance. They reiterate the importance of following the prescribed treatment plan, detailing the purpose of the dosage and medication. Once Pepper is stabilized at the hospital, she is discharged with a detailed medication schedule and written instructions to ensure clarity.

A couple of weeks later, Pepper is rushed to the emergency room and is found to be in the final stages of heart failure. Despite efforts to manage the condition, Pepper passed away suddenly at home from complications related to CHF a few weeks later. Although both the cardiologist and technician agree that CHF would have eventually claimed Pepper’s life, they also recognize that Kasey’s adjustment to the medication likely accelerated her decline.

Devastated, Kasey calls the cardiology team seeking answers and expressing deep guilt over what happened. They confide in the technician, sharing their overwhelming feeling of responsibility for Pepper’s sudden death:

sect3.title: 14.3.2 Anger
sect3.para: The HAB can be deeply rooted and characterized by intense emotional attachment, making the loss of a pet a uniquely challenging and significant experience. Therefore, anger can be another natural response to this loss. This anger may be rooted in feelings of helplessness, guilt, unmet expectations, or the uncertainty surrounding the loss. For instance, the circumstances of the loss can contribute to anger in grief, particularly in cases of sudden or unexpected death caused by accidents or acute illness [ch0027-c14-bib-0004, ch0027-c14-bib-0005]. Unexpected deaths or the difficult decision to euthanize a pet can leave individuals grappling to process the events leading to death and the unresolved questions that remain [ch0027-c14-bib-0004, ch0027-c14-bib-0005]. Clients might direct their anger inward, blaming themselves for the pet’s death or feeling guilt over perceived shortcomings in their care. For some, anger serves as a temporary distraction, allowing them to focus outwardly on blame or frustration instead of confronting the deeply painful feelings of loss.

Veterinary technicians will encounter clients who are angry after the death of their companion. This anger may be due to miscommunication or errors on the part of the veterinary team, but it may also stem from a client’s perception of the veterinary team as the last line of defense against the pet’s illness or death. Regardless of the cause, the client’s anger can be intimidating and difficult to address. Discomfort in handling these situations may lead some veterinary professionals to avoid or ignore angry clients, but this approach is unlikely to improve the situation. It is essential to recognize that anger, though challenging, is a normal response to grief and loss.Chapter 7 has covered strategies for managing conversations with angry clients.

sect2.title: 14.4 Recognizing Grief Responses
sect2.para: There is no one way to experience grief, and this is just as true when someone is experiencing pet loss. The following section is meant to provide general information about different grief responses, which are not limited to pet loss. Technicians should remember that the information below is intended to provide clarification on reactions to death and loss, offering better comprehension of why clients might be behaving a certain way in interactions with the veterinary practice. Under no circumstances should a technician attempt to label or diagnose a client based on the following information.

sect3.title: 14.4.1 Uncomplicated Grief
sect3.para: Uncomplicated grief is sometimes referred to as “normal” grief. However, to avoid implying that other forms of grief are abnormal or bad and to prevent further misunderstanding, it is referred to here as uncomplicated grief. Grief responses are unique to the individual suffering the loss. However, there are certain patterns that grief can follow, which may identify it as uncomplicated. Uncomplicated grief often begins with an acute grief response and gradually shifts into integrated grief ch0027-c14-bib-0006.

listitem.para: Acute grief: An acute grief response typically begins immediately after the loss. There is no specific time frame, but an acute grief response might last from several weeks to a few months depending on an individual’s coping strategies, support systems, and other factors ch0027-c14-bib-0006. It can be characterized by an intense longing for the deceased pet and the presence of emotions such as sadness, guilt, loneliness, shock, anger, or depression ch0027-c14-bib-0006. Individuals experiencing acute grief responses will often feel it disrupts their cognitive function and daily life routines. This can be especially true in pet loss, as pets are often deeply integrated into the structure of their caregiver’s daily routine. For instance, in the first few weeks after a loss, the bereaved may find it hard to focus on daily tasks. Their appetite and sleep patterns may change, and they may even have intrusive imagery around death or loss. The acute nature of this grief is often marked by an eventual decrease in frequency and intensity of feelings of loss ch0027-c14-bib-0006.

Integrated grief: Acute grief gradually transitions into integrated grief ch0027-c14-bib-0006. The bereaved might begin to re‐engage with daily life, such as returning to work, socializing with friends and family, and finding joy in hobbies or activities. During this stage, they may develop new perspectives to cope with their loss, and the intense pain lessens. Although the grief becomes integrated, people still love and miss the pet they have lost. They find new and meaningful ways to continue life while honoring the memory of their beloved companion animal.

sect3.title: 14.4.2 Disenfranchised Grief
sect3.para: Disenfranchised grief occurs when an individual’s loss receives little acknowledgment, recognition, or validation from their social circles or larger community [ch0027-c14-bib-0005, ch0027-c14-bib-0007]. One of the many unique factors involved in pet loss is that it often falls under the umbrella of disenfranchised grief.

Companion animals are widely considered and accepted as a part of family systems. However, there are still societal attitudes that do not view companion animals and their deaths as comparable to those of human beings and human death. In other words, those who do not see or understand the value and importance of the HAB might be more likely to dismiss grief around the death of a pet. Grief is already isolating, and disenfranchised grief can exacerbate this. People grieving a pet may feel pressured to downplay their emotions and minimize their loss to avoid judgment or criticism and fit societal or cultural normsch0027-c14-bib-0007.

Technicians may recognize that their clients struggle with an overwhelming sense of loss while facing open disapproval or lack of acknowledgment from those around them. Clients might express they have received dismissive or insensitive responses and have been met with statements or questions that invalidate their loss experience (Figure 14.3, Case Study 14.3).

sect3.title: 14.4.3 Anticipatory Grief
sect3.para: Anticipatory grief is the feelings and emotions that arise in anticipation of an expected lossch0027-c14-bib-0007. It is not wholly dissimilar from acute grief after the loss. This type of grief response often follows the diagnosis or discovery of a terminal illness or chronic condition, like cancer, but this response is not exclusive to these scenarios. The presence of anticipatory grief does not mean that an individual’s grief will be less intense after the loss has happened. Although anticipatory grief can be common, not everybody who is anticipating a loss will have this experience. This grief response will be encountered by technicians as they collaborate closely with clients around patients’ quality‐of‐life (QOL) assessments, EOL planning, and euthanasia scheduling.

sidebar.title: Case Study 14.3 Lacey and Chewy
sidebar.para: Lacey is pregnant with her first child, who is due in the next two weeks. Although Lacey is excited for the arrival of her firstborn, she is struggling. A week earlier, she had to euthanize her beloved dog of 16 years, a Yorkshire Terrier named Chewy. Lacey reflects on their journey together and how Chewy had been a constant presence in her life. Chewy followed Lacey through major life changes, including marriage, moving homes, career changes, and now pregnancy. The thought that Chewy won't be there to witness the new chapter of welcoming a baby into their lives fills Lacey with a sense of deep sadness.

Despite the well‐intentioned words of comfort from friends and family, Lacey feels the void left by Chewy’s absence. She feels that she cannot share her grief openly, as whenever she expresses her sadness, people respond with statements like: “At least you'll have the baby to focus on soon” or “Don’t be sad! You should be excited about the baby!” Lacey feels ashamed that she is struggling to get excited about her birth. She stops telling people about her grief and keeps to herself instead, hoping that it will help her move on.

para.emphasis: In what ways is disenfranchised grief present in this case?
What are the emotional impacts and consequences for Lacey because of this?

sect3.para: An anticipatory grief response can provide people with an opportunity to prepare for the inevitable loss of their companion animal. This preparation may involve exploring palliative treatment options, engaging in meaningful activities and rituals with their pet, or just spending extra time enjoying each other’s companych0027-c14-bib-0007. It can also allow for the planning of EOL arrangements that honor both the pet who is dying and those who are grieving.

Anticipatory grief can provoke feelings of anxiety and apprehension that come from the unknowns associated with the pet’s condition and future disease progression ch0027-c14-bib-0007. It is common for clients to share with the veterinary team that they cannot stand the thought of having to make an appointment for their pet’s death, or they may have many questions and anxieties around the right time to make an EOL decision.

Anticipatory grief often intersects with another phenomenon called caregiver burden. Caregiver burden refers to the challenges of those who are caregiving for other beings, such as pets, children, or elderly parents. These challenges are often related to the responsibilities that are involved in caring for others. People who are experiencing caregiver burden often struggle with managing the needs of those they care for and their own personal needs and well‐beingch0027-c14-bib-0008. Those who are experiencing caregiver burden and anticipatory grief simultaneously may struggle to navigate the emotional distress of expecting a loss on top of their caregiving responsibilities. If unmanaged and unaddressed, caregiver burden can lead to burnout as an individual becomes so overwhelmed by prolonged stress and exhaustion that they can no longer take care of themselves or others effectively ch0027-c14-bib-0008.

Anticipatory grief is a grief response that is not often recognized by the bereaved person or their support systems. However, it is a genuine experience for those who endure it, and when it is acknowledged and validated, it can empower individuals to talk about it and seek help if needed.

sect3.title: 14.4.4 Prolonged Grief Disorder and Suicidality
sect3.para: Prolonged grief disorder (PGD) was formerly known as complicated grief. It is a grief response that persists over an extended period and has a negative impact on an individual’s ability to function and adapt to life after the lossch0027-c14-bib-0009. The difference between prolonged grief and uncomplicated grief has to do with the integration of this grief into an individual’s life. PGD can be characterized by intense longing for the deceased pet, persistent and unrelenting thoughts about the loss, difficulty accepting the reality of the death, as well as social withdrawal and somatic symptoms such as sleep disturbances or appetite changes ch0027-c14-bib-0010. When someone is experiencing PGD, they are having challenges integrating and adapting to the loss that they have experienced. Individuals might describe themselves as being “stuck” in a certain emotional state for a prolonged period.

There are certain factors that increase the risk of an individual developing PGD. Those who are more susceptible might have pre‐existing mental health conditions, past traumatic experiences, lack of social support, a highly dependent relationship with the deceased pet, or experience death in a sudden or unexpected nature [ch0027-c14-bib-0009, ch0027-c14-bib-0010]. These factors can exacerbate the grieving process, contributing to the persistence of symptoms over time, and even potentially lead to suicidal ideation or intent if not addressed by the appropriate mental health professionals. Responding to suicidality in clients will be addressed further in Chapter 15.

sect2.title: 14.5 Factors Impacting Grief Responses from Pet Loss
sect2.para: There are other factors unique to the HAB that impact how individuals experience pet loss. Technicians might be familiar with many of these factors and come across them as they collaborate with clients around EOL matters. This section will share tips on how technicians can respond to clients impacted by these scenarios. A more thorough guide to ways technicians can support pet loss is presented inChapter 15.

sect3.title: 14.5.1 Euthanasia
sect3.para: Technicians will be familiar with the procedure of euthanasia as it is well integrated with veterinary EOL care. Many recognize euthanasia as a humane and compassionate choice to end an animal’s suffering and pain and provide a peaceful transition to death. The ability to choose euthanasia can be an empowering one for caregivers, but it can also be a significant source of anxiety, guilt, and other distressing emotions.

A euthanasia decision is best made in conjunction with veterinary medical professionals. This allows caregivers to receive expert guidance and support to make this difficult decision in a collaborative way (seeChapter 8 for further information on EOL decision‐making). When the situation offers the ability to plan a beloved pet’s EOL well in advance, this can allow caregivers some control in a situation where there is otherwise very little. Euthanasia is truly a final act of caring. A compassionate euthanasia experience has been shown to have a positive impact on the grief responses of pet parents (Case Study 14.4) ch0027-c14-bib-0011.

Considering the option to euthanize can cause distress for pet caregivers, and technicians may notice they have conflicting emotions and perspectives. For instance, caregivers may experience feelings of guilt and self‐doubt about choosing this option, or they might have hesitation about the morality of this act and how it will impact their bond with their pet. Furthermore, there are times when a planned euthanasia does not go as expected. As discussed inChapter 10, dysthanasia refers to a euthanasia procedure with complications or one that is performed in a way that causes unnecessary suffering and pain to an animal ch0027-c14-bib-0012. When dysthanasia occurs, it can exacerbate the caregiver’s feelings of regret, guilt, and sadness, potentially leaving them with anger and distrust towards themselves or the veterinary practice ch0027-c14-bib-0012. These scenarios can potentially intensify an individual’s grief response. Technicians can play a key role in navigating conversations around euthanasia with sensitivity and compassion. Technicians can ensure that caregivers’ and families’ feelings are heard and validated through the process of saying goodbye to their beloved companion animals and beyond.

sidebar.title: Case Study 14.4 Jenna and Muggs
sidebar.para: Jenna has had Muggs, an Old English Sheepdog, in her life for 12 years. Muggs is her self‐described “heart dog,” and they are very bonded. For the past two to three years, Muggs has been in and out of the veterinary practice for the management of multiple chronic conditions. Jenna and the veterinary team have had many discussions regarding QOL and EOL. In the last month, Muggs’s QOL has taken a turn for the worse, and Jenna has decided it is time to book an appointment for euthanasia.

The technician had a conversation with Jenna the day before the appointment regarding emotional support and her concerns about the procedure and aftercare. On the day of the appointment, Jenna spends a lot of time with Muggs, who is happy and eating snacks in the comfort room. She has brought in his favorite blanket and all his favorite toys. The goodbye is peaceful, which resonates deeply with Jenna. She finds that the goodbye has brought her great comfort.

para.emphasis: Jenna found peace in Muggs’ goodbye. How might this experience also positively impact the technician, both professionally and personally?

sect3.title: 14.5.2 Sudden Loss
sect3.para: A sudden loss refers to a loss that has happened very unexpectedly. This loss may have been the result of a tragic accident or death from illness without warning. In a study released by the American Psychological Association, researchers identified that losing a human in an unexpected or sudden event increased the risk of the bereaved experiencing PGD. They were also noted to have more severe and persistent psychological reactions like post‐traumatic stress disorderch0027-c14-bib-0013.

Losing a pet in any context can be heartbreaking. However, the sudden loss of a pet may add a layer of devastation to the grief. Technicians who work with clients enduring the sudden loss of their companion animal may notice these individuals experience shock, confusion, anger, and overwhelming intense emotions. These clients often struggle with unknowns and unanswered questions surrounding their pet’s death. Caregivers may find themselves in a never‐ending loop of “what‐ifs” or feeling distrust in themselves or their veterinary teams. There are also times when a caregiver’s or family member’s actions inadvertently lead to their companion’s death, and as a result, they may experience intense guilt, anger, or deep shame in themselves (Case Study 14.5).

In these scenarios, technicians will need to demonstrate empathy and understanding for their clients. It is especially important that the EOL care team is mindful of having a nonjudgmental attitude toward clients. They should prepare for the possibility of having intense emotions directed at the team. Technicians should keep a calm and nonreactive demeanor, and recognize that this is likely a projection of the client’s grief. It is helpful to express empathy and offer resources for grief support. Of course, this does not mean staff should tolerate abusive behavior (seeChapter 7 for more information on supporting difficult conversations).

sidebar.title: Case Study 14.5 Louise and Max
sidebar.para: Louise is a stay‐at‐home mother. During the day, she cares for her two young children and Max, the family’s three‐year‐old border collie. During a busy morning, Louise realizes that the back door to the house has been left open, and Max is nowhere to be seen. She rushes outside, searching for him, and eventually finds that he was accidentally struck by the neighbor’s car while running onto the road. Despite being rushed to the emergency hospital, Max’s injuries are fatal, and he dies shortly after.

In the wake of Max’s death, Louise is consumed by guilt and self‐blame. She agonizes over whether she had secured the garage door or if one of her children had inadvertently left it open. Each moment replays in her mind, and she constantly is reminded of images of Max in his final moments. Despite her family and friends’ attempts to console her, Louise finds herself battling with self‐blame and intense grief. She is angry at herself for not being more vigilant, especially knowing Max’s tendency to escape, which he has done before. She has nightmares about his final days and believes she has failed Max.

para.emphasis: Louise is dealing with guilt and self‐blame after a tragic accident. How might these feelings impact her grief?

sect3.title: 14.5.3 Loss of Service Animals
sect3.para: Service animals play dual roles as both cherished companions to an individual and an aid helping them through daily function. The termservice animal is distinct from emotional support animal ch0027-c14-bib-0014. Service animals are trained to perform tasks or work with individuals with physical, psychiatric, intellectual, and mental health‐related disabilities (see Figure 14.4). These animals, most commonly dogs, assist with physical tasks or medical alerts that are essential for a person’s daily function and quality of life. For example, a trained guide dog for a blind individual is considered a service animal. Service animals are allowed access to public spaces and accommodations. Emotional support animals offer comfort and support for a person’s physical and mental health through affection and companionship. Unlike service animals, they do not require specific training or certification to perform specific tasks, and their access to public spaces and accommodations is limited ch0027-c14-bib-0014.

sect3.para: Humans can form a very deep bond with service animals. This bond fosters confidence, self‐esteem, independence, and a sense of security. Given the level of support these companions provide, their death can be incredibly impactful. Technicians should note the added element of support in these relationships and how this loss can lead to significant emotional and practical challenges for the client.

sect3.title: 14.5.4 Culture and Spirituality
sect3.para: Culture and spirituality can have a considerable influence on how people conceptualize and cope with loss. Cultural practices, like rituals and ceremonies, create spaces where individuals can mourn their loss openly without fear or judgment. These practices may also serve to validate that the loss is acknowledged and accepted by a larger community. This is especially important for pet loss, as the bereaved risk becoming disenfranchised in their grief.

Cultural practices are often (but not always) entwined with spiritual beliefs. In many cases, individuals will find comfort in spirituality as it provides context for understanding and coping with death and loss. These belief systems help individuals find meaning in their loss; they may offer peace of mind through the idea of an afterlife or reincarnation; they can even help the bereaved maintain a sense of connection to their petsch0027-c14-bib-0015. For a caregiver who is grieving their companion animal, they may turn to these factors to help them process and memorialize the loss.

Conversely, culture and spirituality can sometimes cause distress and conflicting emotions around death and grief (Case Study 14.6). In cultures where pets are not considered important family members, grieving may be seen as inappropriate, resulting in individuals minimizing their loss and feeling shame or embarrassment ch0027-c14-bib-0015. There are cultures that do not have established rituals or ceremonies for pet loss. The bereaved may find they have less guidance, social support, and acknowledgment for their grief ch0027-c14-bib-0015. Spiritual beliefs can also pose challenges when they conflict with the grieving process, such as religions that minimize the significance of pet loss, causing guilt or confusion for those grieving their pets ch0027-c14-bib-0016.

sidebar.title: Case Study 14.6 Tam and Lily
sidebar.para: Tam was born and raised in rural Vietnam before immigrating to Canada with his wife and infant daughter. It has been many years since this move, and they have all settled in Canada. His daughter is now grown up and not living at home. Before his daughter moved away, she brought home a chihuahua puppy named Lily. Tam was annoyed about this at first. He had never grown up with pets or wanted one. Where he grew up, animals were owned with the sole purpose of completing working tasks; however, Lily quickly changed his mind. Tam became deeply bonded with Lily. Their routines became integrated, and this became even more true when she developed a chronic health condition. Tam tracks Lily’s medications, behaviors, and bowel movements so he can stay on top of her medical management and care.

Eventually, Tam must make the difficult decision to euthanize Lily at the age of 12, when her condition is no longer manageable and her QOL declines significantly. Tam is heartbroken. He struggles with her absence and has difficulty adjusting to life without her. Tam keeps this deep pain to himself as he feels that in his culture, his grief for a dog would likely not be understood or accepted. He doesn’t even tell his immediate family that he is struggling. Tam brings Lily’s ashes with him on his walks and cries. He does not feel ready to do this activity they once shared without her. He worries his family and friends will find out about his intense grief and think there’s something wrong with him. He is ashamed of his grief.

para.emphasis: In what ways do you think Tam keeping this intense grief to himself might impact his grieving process?

sect3.para: Cultural and spiritual sensitivity is a valuable skill for technicians as they navigate providing compassionate support to grieving clients. Technicians do not need to be experts on the cultures and beliefs of others. Practicing cultural sensitivity means allowing an open mind and recognizing the value and influence of these factors on people’s attitudes toward the EOL and death.

sect3.title: 14.5.5 Perceived Social Support
sect3.para: The perceived social support an individual receives after a loss is incredibly important. As mentioned previously, pet loss may result in disenfranchised grief, which puts bereaved individuals at risk of feeling lonely and isolated. A companion animal is often considered a social support for many people. Their pets are a source of constant, unwavering love through major life events and transitions. Losing a companion animal may mean losing a key member of a support network.

Social support has been shown to enhance individuals’ ability to cope and process their loss more effectively, acting as a potential preventative factor of PGDch0027-c14-bib-0017. A support network might include family and friends, online groups or forums, and professionals such as counselors (Case Study 14.7). Effective support in the case of pet loss might include someone who will provide empathic listening, a nonjudgmental space to mourn, and sharing in remembering important dates or memories about the pet. These connections are most effective when maintained and fostered over time. When people feel disconnected from a support system or only receive support for a limited time, they risk their grief becoming disenfranchised ch0027-c14-bib-0017.

sidebar.title: Case Study 14.7 John and Charlie
sidebar.para: John is 45 years old and lives at home with his 7‐year‐old German Shepherd, Charlie. John spent Charlie’s puppy years training him and teaching him commands. He is very proud of Charlie’s achievements. Charlie is smart, loving, and attentive to John, who is happy to return the favor. They are best friends! John is not close with his family and has a small social circle, but he does enjoy the company of his neighbors, all of whom have dogs. Together with a group of neighbors, John would walk every evening with their companions.

Sadly, Charlie was diagnosed with osteosarcoma and died shortly after. John grieves for Charlie at home and doesn't share the loss with any of his coworkers or family members, as Charlie was his confidante. He only shares this loss with his neighbors to let them know he won't be joining their nightly walks. Initially, his neighbors give him space and offer their condolences, but after a few days, they come knocking on his door, convincing him to join them for a walk and offering for him to walk one of their dogs. They continue to visit him every night to ensure he joins them. Touched by this gesture, John feels grateful. He hadn't thought anyone would care and did not want to be a burden by sharing his grief. However, with the companionship of his neighbors and their dogs, he starts to feel better day by day. He appreciates that they ask about Charlie and continue to check‐in.

para.emphasis: Why do you think it was helpful for John that his neighbors continued to check‐in with him and invite him for walks?

sect3.para: The technician and veterinary team often are considered a support system by their clients. These professionals have potentially followed clients through the life cycle of their companions, helped care for them, and acknowledged the importance of the HAB. This means technicians are in an ideal position to offer words of comfort, empathic listening, and even a gentle perspective on the loss.

sect3.title: 14.5.6 Age
sect3.para: Grief impacts people at any stage of their life. For older adults and children, there are key considerations that the technician should recognize when supporting these demographics through pet loss. Children and pet loss are discussed thoroughly inChapter 16, so the focus of this section is on older adults.

There is well‐established evidence that companion animals significantly impact healthy aging in the context of supporting emotional well‐being and promoting physical activitych0027-c14-bib-0018. These relationships can hold deep meaning for older adults, who often share that their pet provided them with a sense of purpose through caregiving, tangible and emotional connection, and an overall sense of companionship (see Figure 14.5).

The death of a pet can mean an added layer of consequences and challenges for older adults. As people journey through their lifecycles, loss happens more frequently. This might mean the shrinking of social circles or personal lifestyle changes and adjustments such as living alone, declining health, or reduced income. All these changes impact the opportunity to engage in social connections ch0027-c14-bib-0019. These factors may mean that older individuals are more isolated and more likely to experience disenfranchised grief.

sect3.para: There can be an added sense of finality to losing a pet. Many older adults express that they are less inclined to get a new companion after a loss because they are concerned about their own health status or not being able to fulfill the care responsibilities needed for their petch0027-c14-bib-0020. Older adults may harbor a sense of failure if they feel that they were not able to properly care for the pet’s deteriorating illness due to their own health limitations (Case Study 14.8).

sidebar.title: Case Study 14.8 Don and Princess
sidebar.para: Don has always loved cats and has a particular affinity for calicos. He is 70 years old and lives alone with his feline companion, a 10‐year‐old calico named Princess. Princess and Don share a special connection; she was with him when he lost his mother to cancer nine years ago, which was a devastating loss. He attributes his ability to survive that tough time to having Princess by his side. Don has no children or spouse, and he and Princess spend their days together enjoying the sunshine on the deck and watching TV. He never feels lonely with her around.

Recently, Princess developed serious kidney issues and has been in and out of the hospital. She began to lose her appetite and became so unwell that Don made the difficult decision to euthanize her. The loss has been gut‐wrenching. With few people to talk to and his own health issues making it hard to leave the house and stay busy, Don dearly misses Princess. He starts looking at pictures of Calicos for adoption, although he isn’t quite ready to adopt yet. He has always had a cat in his home. The more Don thinks about adopting, the more concerns arise. He often wonders if he would outlive a new cat or if he could care for them properly should his own health decline. He struggles with age being a consideration for having a new cat.

para.emphasis: What does Don’s hesitation to bring a new cat into his life say about the fears and uncertainties that can accompany both grief and aging?

sect3.para: Veterinary teams working with older adults experiencing pet loss should be aware of the challenges this demographic faces. Technicians working in EOL care can take multiple actions to support these individuals: offer resources that connect older adults to the community, follow up after the loss to check in, and validate the significance of this relationship and the HAB.

sect2.title: 14.6 Considerations for a Grieving Pet
sect2.para: Caregivers and families who are grieving their deceased companion may also notice behavioral changes in other household pets and express these concerns to the veterinary team. It is not possible to say with certainty why these changes are happening. Maybe it is because the other companion animal is grieving, or it may be that they are reacting to their caregiver’s grief. In any case, a deceased pet is a loss that impacts routines and daily functions, which can indeed cause the rest of the household pets to act differentlych0027-c14-bib-0021. Loss of human family members can also result in similar signs of grief in pets.

Technicians may notice that caregivers are worried and struggling to find ways to support their other pets’ emotional well‐being while also navigating their own immense grief. They may even try to suppress their emotions so they do not upset their other pets. Technicians can provide reassurance and help guide the caregiver in supporting the other animals in multiple ways:ch0027-c14-bib-0021

listitem.para: validate the family’s grief experience
encourage monitoring of the other pet(s)
suggest a physical exam to rule out medical conditions
explore anxiety‐management strategies (e.g. calming pheromones or supplements)
encourage families to show lots of love and affection to the other pet(s)
offer pet loss resources and safe spaces to support grieving (support groups and professional counseling)
encourage the family to maintain familiar routines

sect2.para: Most pets who are impacted by grief can fully resolve these changes with support from the caregiver. Technicians can also prepare clients to consider the benefit of including their other animals in the EOL process. This can include bringing other companion animals from the household to an in‐clinic euthanasia or allowing them to be present for a home euthanasia. It can also simply be allowing the other animal(s) to see the body after death. It is important to consider how the presence of the other animal may impact the environment and experience for the caregivers before making these decisions. If another animal is going to be included at EOL, the client should be counseled away from having any expectations of their behavior at that moment. Other pets may show a variety of responses ranging from direct interaction and even affection with the body through to total avoidance. Just as responses to death are individual in people, we must also accept each animal’s response without assigning anything further to it, such as a lack of caring for the deceased pet.

listitem.para: Understanding the unique process of grief allows technicians to provide more compassionate EOL experiences.
Grief is a highly individualized and unique process for each person.
The close HAB may result in feelings of guilt, regret, or anger after a companion has died.
Caregivers may experience disenfranchised grief, anticipatory grief, or PGD with possible suicidal ideation following the loss of a pet.
Culture, spirituality, caregiver age, and access to social support impact the way caregivers experience the grieving process.
Veterinary technicians familiar with the terminology and individualized nature of grief are better equipped to support caregivers through their experience.
14.1 Diane, Christian, and Speckle
14.2 Kasey and Pepper
14.3 Lacey and Chewy
14.4 Jenna and Muggs
14.5 Louise and Max
14.6 Tam and Lily
14.7 John and Charlie
14.8 Don and Princess
Both Diane and Christian are grieving the loss of Speckle. Diane is also mourning this loss by expressing her sadness and grief openly to the vet staff and her partner.

Everybody is different when it comes to experiencing grief. We might not know why Christian responds this way, but we do know that just because Christian doesn’t appear to mourn this death doesn’t mean he isn’t grieving the loss.

The technician created a supportive and nonjudgmental space that allowed Kasey to openly express feelings of guilt and grief. Understanding Kasey’s need to process these emotions and that their intent was to be helpful, the technician conveyed empathy and compassion while gently reinforcing the importance of following medical guidance for Pepper’s care. By providing resources to help Kasey manage their grief and address feelings of guilt without downplaying the significance of consulting professionals, the technician balanced education and emotional support.

In this example, Lacey may feel that her grief for Chewy is being downplayed or unacknowledged by her support system. Friends and family focus on her upcoming baby, unintentionally minimizing her sorrow over Chewy’s death. She also feels pressured to “move on” to fit the expected joy of impending motherhood. As a result, she experiences shame and begins to self‐censor, feeling that her grief is something to be hidden.

Lacey might be feeling isolated, as she feels she lacks the space to express her emotions openly. She experiences guilt and self‐doubt, questioning the validity of her sadness because she believes she should feel only joy. Suppressing her grief might lead to prolonged sadness and unresolved emotions.

This peaceful and meaningful goodbye may provide the technician with a sense of fulfillment and reassurance, knowing they helped create a compassionate, comfortable, and safe experience for both Jenna and Muggs.

Louise’s feelings of guilt and self‐blame might intensify and complicate her grief. Her persistent self‐blame may lead her to relive the incident repeatedly, fixating on what she could have done differently. This can prevent her from finding perspective, as she may struggle with feelings of inadequacy and failure. Instead of processing her grief, Louise might become stuck in a cycle of regret and guilt, which can prolong her mourning and make it more challenging for her to heal emotionally.

Tam keeping his intense grief to himself may complicate his grieving process by preventing him from fully processing and expressing his emotions. Without the support and validation from others he may feel isolated in his pain. This isolation could intensify his feelings of shame and self‐doubt, reinforcing his belief that his grief is inappropriate. Additionally, without external acknowledgment or a safe space to share his sorrow, Tam might struggle to work through this loss, potentially impacting his mental health and overall well‐being.

It was helpful for John that his neighbors continued to check in and invite him for walks because it provided him with a sense of connection and support during his grief. The companionship and understanding of his neighbors helped him feel less isolated and reminded him that he was not alone in his loss and that his grief was valid. By including him in their routine and offering their own dogs for him to walk, his neighbors allowed John to maintain an important part of his routine and engage in supportive human connections.

Don’s concerns reflect apprehension about forming new attachments after loss, as well as worries about his own mortality and declining health. Don’s reluctance suggests an awareness of his limitations and a fear of potentially outliving a new pet, emphasizing how aging can complicate decisions around companionship and responsibility in later life. This hesitancy reveals the emotional weight of grief and the practical considerations that aging individuals may face when contemplating new bonds.
